section.title: Introduction
section.para: This specification defines the standard structure and vocabulary of XDI cryptographic concepts and features, including keys, key pairs, encryption, signatures, digests, and tokens.
This builds on the basic XDI graph model (see ) and is used in XDI Messaging (see ) and XDI Link Contracts (see ).

section.para: The key words must, must not, required, shall, shall not, should, should not, recommended, may, and optional are to be interpreted as described in . Note that for reasons of style, these words are not capitalized in this document.

section.title: XDI Cryptography
section.para: TODO.
Note that many dictionary terms such as <$key> or <$token> that are defined in this specification are by themselves not expressive enough to be useful for concrete cryptographic operations.

Therefore, the meaning and purpose of such basic dictionary terms are commonly enhanced by subsumption relationships (i.e. $is# type relations), by composition relationships (i.e. contextual relations, see section Core Relations in ), and/or by the specialization pattern (i.e. a sequence of identifiers, see section Core Relations in ).

section.title: Scope and Normalization
section.para: Encryption (see ) as well as signatures (see ) always apply to a certain set of XDI statements that get encrypted or signed. This set of XDI statements is called the scope of the cryptographic method. The scope may be:

listitem.para: All XDI statements in a graph
All XDI statements rooted in one or more subgraphs
A single XDI statement
Any arbitrary set of XDI statements

section.para: In order to produce a sequence of bytes that can be used as input for encryption and signatures, the XDI statements within the scope have to be serialized in a normalized form. This is done using the following algorithm:

listitem.para: A temporary scope graph is constructed that contains exactly the XDI statements within the scope.

The scope graph is serialized using the XDI JSON serialization format (see XDI JSON Format Serialization Rules in ) with the following properties:
The implied parameter is set to 0.
Apply rules for alphabetically ordering XDI statements in the JSON object structure ( see Readability Rules in ).
The serialized scope graph is encoded in UTF-8 to produce a sequence of bytes.

section.title: Cryptographic Key Pairs: $keypair
section.para: A cryptographic key pair is represented as an XDI entity in a graph. It may be either an entity singleton identified by a $keypair context:
Or it may be a member of an entity collection identified by a [$keypair] context.

section.title: Algorithm
section.para: A $keypair entity SHOULD have a $is# type relation, in order to express the cryptographic algorithm used to produce the key pair.
XDI processors MUST support the following key pair algorithms:

listitem.para: $rsa$2048: 2048 bit RSA key pair
$dsa$2048: 2048 bit DSA key pair
$ed25519: 32 byte Ed25519 key pair on the Curve25519 elliptic curve

section.title: Cryptographic Keys: <$key>
section.para: A cryptographic key is represented as an XDI attribute in a graph. It may be either an attribute singleton identified by a <$key> context:
Or it may be a member of an attribute collection identified by a [<$key>] context.
The literal value of the attribute is the key encoded in a certain format:
A <$key> attribute may be specialized by a <$public> attribute to identify a cryptographic public key used in asymmetric cryptography:
For cryptographic public keys, XDI processors MUST support:

listitem.para: RSA public keys in PEM-encoded X.509 format
DSA public keys in PEM-encoded X.509 format

section.para: A <$public><$key> attribute MAY be placed under a $keypair entity, in order to express a composition relationship between a key pair and a public key:
A <$key> attribute may be specialized by a <$private> attribute to identify a cryptographic private key:
For cryptographic private keys, XDI processors MUST support:

listitem.para: RSA public keys in PEM-encoded PKCS #8 format
DSA public keys in PEM-encoded PKCS #8 format

section.para: A <$private><$key> attribute MAY be placed under a $keypair entity, in order to express a composition relationship between a key pair and a private key:
A <$key> attribute may be specialized by a <$secret> attribute to identify a cryptographic secret key used in symmetric cryptography:
For cryptographic secret keys, XDI processors MUST support:

listitem.para: AES secret keys in Base64-encoded byte format

section.title: Algorithm
section.para: A <$key> attribute SHOULD have a $is# type relation, in order to express the cryptographic algorithm used to produce the key.
XDI processors MUST support the following key algorithms:

listitem.para: $rsa$2048: 2048 bit RSA key
$dsa$2048: 2048 bit DSA key
$aes$256: 256 bit AES secret key
$ed25519: 32 byte Ed25519 key on the Curve25519 elliptic curve

section.title: Signatures: <$sig>
section.para: A cryptographic signature is represented as an XDI attribute in a graph. It may be either an attribute singleton identified by a <$sig> context:
Or it may be a member of an attribute collection identified by a [<$sig>] context.
The literal value of the attribute is the signature encoded in Base64:

section.title: Scope
section.para: The scope of the cryptographic signature by default includes all XDI statements rooted in the parent context of the <$sig> attribute, EXCLUDING:

listitem.para: All XDI statements rooted in the <$sig> attribute, and
The contextual statement that establishes the <$sig> attribute itself.

section.title: Algorithm
section.para: A <$sig> attribute SHOULD have a $is# type relation, in order to express the cryptographic algorithm used to produce the signature.
XDI processors MUST support the following signature algorithms:

listitem.para: $sha$256$rsa$2048: signature produced by a 2048 bit RSA private key and the SHA-256 cryptographic hash function
$sha$256$dsa$2048: signature produced by a 2048 bit DSA private key and the SHA-256 cryptographic hash function
$sha$256$aes$256: message authentication code (MAC) produced by a 256 bit AES secret key and the SHA-256 cryptographic hash function
$ed25519$64: 64 byte signature produced by the Ed25519 signature algorithm on the Curve25519 elliptic curve
$ecdsa$64: signature produced by the ECDSA signature algorithm on the P-256 elliptic curve
